dfc85068874c.name: GV Library
dfc85068874c.description: Advice, lessons, and tips from GV partners and our community of entrepreneurs.
dfc85068874c.shortDescription: Advice, lessons, and tips from GV partners and our…

paragraphs.name: f912
paragraphs.text: Everyone is a designer. Get over it.

paragraphs.name: f37f
paragraphs.text: Maybe that’s why so many designers are offended when non-designers do design work or get called “designers” by Jared and me. You can act offended if you want, but the reality is that other people are making design decisions with or without you. Embrace them . They don’t make your job less valuable. They don’t make your job title less meaningful.

paragraphs.name: 33c1
paragraphs.text: Whether you like it or not, whether you approve it or not, people outside of your design team are making significant design choices that affect your customers in important ways. They are designing your product. They are designers.

paragraphs.name: f2f3
paragraphs.text: Focusing on the core business is what differentiates real product design from interface design or even user experience design. Fundamental product design is really hard and requires a lot of legwork, but this is what designers at the highest level do — and it’s why their work is better than yours.

paragraphs.name: ed87
paragraphs.text: This shouldn’t be provocative — it’s just a statement of fact. I work with dozens of startups every year, and I see it happen at every one. A CFO makes a pricing decision and changes the product experience. An engineer makes a performance trade-off. A salesperson calls on a customer. In my view, people who fundamentally change the customer’s experience are designers.

paragraphs.name: c872
paragraphs.text: Having more people who do design is additive, not competitive. These designers make your team and your product stronger, because they’re contributing from their unique perspectives. Help them bolster their skills, and use their expertise to the advantage of your product and company.
Does everyone need all the skills of a designer? Of course not. But each person needs to be armed with the tools to understand how their decisions affect the customer experience.

fa9c622a51e3.title: Whether it’s competitive or additive depends on the (job title) designer’s mindset.

paragraphs.name: 8c22
paragraphs.text: Whether it’s competitive or additive depends on the (job title) designer’s mindset. Some designers crave control and want to be “the hero” who solves the problem. They want to go in hiding, build their exact vision then show it to an impressed audience of colleagues. I know, because that was me, 5 years ago.

paragraphs.name: eff8
paragraphs.text: Having an influence or impact on the experience is not the same as being a designer of that experience. There are lots of grey areas on how a design can be influenced. Your dev team may both influence AND design elements of the work but they may not design the overall experience.

paragraphs.text: This is the TL;DR of the TWO articles written about this idea. Apply this idea to where you fit into an organization — it isn’t a unique trait to Designers. It doesn’t make you a designer, but it will make you really successful at what you do. A user-centered Marketer, a user-center Engineer, a user-center Product Manager, etc.

paragraphs.text: I find it incredible that there are designers who feel threatened by this concept. Having more people within an organization thinking about design not only makes the product better, but it makes a designer’s job easier so they can do greater work.

ac9cc1fe228e.title: I would agree, but only if they are doing so intentionally, with the customer experience in mind.

paragraphs.name: a4ef
paragraphs.text: I would agree, but only if they are doing so intentionally, with the customer experience in mind. An engineer who makes a decision based on internal processes that just happens to affect the customer experience is not designing anything.

dc305c368e4d.title: I embrace the idea that design is in its very nature is collaborative, and that everybody and…

paragraphs.name: 63d0
paragraphs.text: I embrace the idea that design is in its very nature is collaborative, and that everybody and anybody can contribute to the user experience. But I think is messy and inarticulate to call people in other roles “designers.” They have made a design decision — just like I might make a marketing or engineering decision — but that does not make them…
